title: Ticket #7500: Clients should not suggest authentication methods they don't support
description:
We had a surprisingly long security-handshake-debugging session that came down to the fact that the client will happily suggest to the server various authentication methods that it doesn't support. It's only later, when the client and server are exchanging integers, that the client silently refuses to use the suggested protocol.

Can we:

  1. Note at at least at D_FULLDEBUG (maybe D_SECURITY? D_ALWAYS?) when the sysadmin has configured an unknown protocol name?
  2. Similarly, when the client is rejecting unsupported protocols from the server, we should note this reason in the logs.
remarks:
2020-Apr-18 18:45:19 by tlmiller:
Code Review

Fixed a non-const char * warning.

Otherwise this looks sane, although I wonder if it makes sense to have the READ-implies-CLAIMSTOBE special case tucked away in getDefaultAuthenticationMethods(). I don't know enough about the logic of the special case to tell if it's actually intrinsic in the default authentication methods or if it only applies to the caller.
